List of vaccine in India
1) Covishield
2) Covaxin
3) Sputnik V

Covishield
The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine is being manufactured locally by the Serum Institute of
India, the world's largest vaccine manufacturer. It says it is producing more than 60
million doses a month. The jab is administered in two doses given between four and 12
weeks apart. The jab developed by Pfizer-BioNTech, which is currently being administered
in several countries, must be stored at -70C and can only be moved a limited number of
times - a particular challenge in India, where summer temperatures can reach 50C.
It was found to be 70% effective after the first dose.

Covaxin
Covaxin is an inactivated vaccine which means that it is made up of killed coronaviruses, making it safe to be injected into the body. Bharat Biotech, a 24-year-old vaccine maker
with a portfolio of 16 vaccines and exports to 123 countries, used a sample of the
coronavirus, isolated by India's National Institute of Virology.

The vaccine has an efficacy rate of 81%, preliminary data from its phase 3 trial shows.
Bharat Biotech says it has a stockpile of 20 million doses of Covaxin, and is aiming to
make 700 million doses out of its four facilities in two cities by the end of the year.

Sputnik V
Russia's Sputnik V has been deemed to be safe, and works in a way similar to the
Oxford-AstraZeneca jab which is being made in India as Covishield. Sputnik V gives around 92% protection against Covid-19, late stage trial results published in The Lancet reveal.

Side Effects of Covishield
Some mild symptoms may occur like:
1) Injection site tenderness
2) Injection site pain
3) Headache
4) Fatigue
5) Myalgia
6) Malaise
7) Pyrexia
8) Chills
9) Arthralgia
10) Nausea

Side Effects of Covaxin
Some mild symptoms AEFIs may occur like:
1) Injection site pain
2) Headache
3) Fatigue
4) Fever
5) Body ache
6) Abdominal pain
7) Nausea
8) Vomiting
9) Dizziness-giddiness,
10) Tremor
11) Sweating
12) Cold
13) Cough
14) Injection site swelling.

Side Effects of Sputnik V
Some mild symptoms may occur like:
1) Fatigue(70%)
2) Joint Pain(46.4%)
3) Headache(64.7%)
4) Muscle ache(61.5%)
5) Chills(45.4%)
6) Fever(15.6%)

Please ask about specific vaccines from the following:
1) Covishield
2) Covaxin
3) Sputnik V

patterns: Where should I register for the vaccination?
Where can I get the vaccine from?
responses: Register on the Co-WIN Portal and schedule your vaccination appointment. https://www.cowin.gov.in/home

patterns: What is the dose schedule of both the vaccines?
When should I take the second dose?
responses:
The time interval between two doses of the Covishield vaccine should be 12-16 weeks. The second dose of Covaxin can be taken four to six weeks after the first.
Source

patterns: Do I have a choice of vaccine I will receive?
responses: The vaccine will be supplied to various parts of India as per availability and distribution plan, beneficiaries load and so at present the option of choice of vaccine is not available.

patterns: Am I eligible for the vaccine
responses:
From May 1, 2021, all eligible citizens above the age of 18 years can get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Source

patterns: Am I eligible for the vaccine
responses:
From May 1, 2021, all eligible citizens above the age of 18 years can get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Source

There is no head-to-head comparison done between the two vaccines being used in India so one cannot choose one over the other. Both would work fine in preventing the infection as well as prevent a person from going into severe state of the disease. As a long-term effect, it would be preventing death for elderly people or those who have comorbidities.
Source

patterns: Do I need to use the mask/other COVID-19 appropriate precautions after receiving the vaccine?
Do I need to wear a mask after vaccination?
responses:
Yes, it is absolutely necessary that everyone who has received the COVID-19 vaccine should continue to follow the COVID-19 appropriate behaviour i.e., mask, do gaj ki doori and hand sanitization to protect themselves and those around from spreading the infection.
Source
